name: Microweber
tagline: Open-source drag-and-drop CMS & e-commerce builder
description: Microweber is an open-source, drag-and-drop CMS and e-commerce platform that lets you build websites, online stores, and blogs without coding. It offers product management, multiple payment gateways (Stripe, PayPal), shipping options, and inventory tracking for e-commerce. Deploy via Docker, shared hosting, or VPS (supports PHP/MySQL). Features include multilingual support, SEO tools, responsive design, modular plugins/themes, and real-time previews—ideal for small businesses wanting self-hosted control.
pros: Self-hosted with full data privacy and control
Core platform is free and open-source (no subscription fees)
cons: Requires PHP/MySQL hosting (technical setup for self-hosting)
Premium add-ons needed for advanced e-commerce features
Less enterprise-level support than SaaS alternatives

faqs.question: Is Microweber hard to install?
faqs.answer: Microweber is easy to install: use Docker for containerized deployment, upload files to a PHP/MySQL host, or use one-click installers like Softaculous. Official docs provide step-by-step guides for all methods.

faqs.question: Is it a good alternative to Shopify?
faqs.answer: Yes—great for users wanting self-hosted control and no recurring fees. It lacks Shopify’s enterprise features but offers core e-commerce tools plus drag-and-drop building, perfect for small/medium stores.

faqs.question: Is it completely free?
faqs.answer: The core platform is free, open-source, and modifiable. Premium plugins, themes, or support services cost extra but are optional for basic/intermediate use cases.

name: Odoo POS
tagline: Open-source point-of-sale system for e-commerce & retail businesses
description: Odoo POS is a flexible open-source POS solution designed for e-commerce and retail. It supports offline sales, real-time inventory sync with e-commerce stores, multi-store management, and payment gateway integrations (credit cards, mobile payments). Deployable via self-hosted servers, Docker containers, or Odoo’s cloud platform, it integrates seamlessly with Odoo’s e-commerce module to unify in-store and online sales data. Ideal for small to medium businesses, it includes barcode scanning, receipt printing, and customer loyalty program features.
pros: No recurring subscription fees for core features
Seamless integration with Odoo’s e-commerce ecosystem
cons: Requires technical setup for self-hosting
Limited advanced features in the free community edition
Steeper learning curve for non-technical users

faqs.question: Is Odoo POS hard to install?
faqs.answer: Odoo POS can be installed via Docker (simplified setup), self-hosted servers (needs basic sysadmin skills), or Odoo’s cloud platform (one-click deployment). Cloud options are ideal for non-technical users, while self-hosting offers full control.

faqs.question: Is it a good alternative to Shopify POS?
faqs.answer: Yes—Odoo POS is a strong alternative for businesses wanting self-hosted control and integration with a complete e-commerce suite. Unlike Shopify POS, it avoids platform lock-in and has no mandatory subscription fees for core features, though Shopify may have more pre-built third-party integrations.

faqs.question: Is it completely free?
faqs.answer: The core POS module in Odoo’s Community Edition is 100% free and open source (MIT license). Enterprise features like advanced reporting or 24/7 support require a paid subscription, but self-hosting the community version has no license costs.
